title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: We passed between Alderney and the French coast — Cape de la Hague — and saw the other side of Alderney; and then, later, Sark, Guernsey, and the other islands.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: You look over the bay of GiLemiscy, and see opposite to you the islands of Hcrm, yethou, and Sark ; with Alderney,  and the coast of France, Cape dc la Hague, to the left in the distance, and to the right in the distance, Jersey.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: This island with its bold point, and the little one of Cornet with a sort of castle on it (close to which we were anchored), and the three islands of Herm, Jcthou, and Sark, with innumerable rocks, are really very fine and peculiar, — especially as they then were in bright sunlight.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: You see Sark (or Scrcq) as you enter the harbour to the right, and further on, close opposite St. Pierre, two islands close together — Herm and JetJioti.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: Yousee Sark (or Sercq) as you enter the harbor to theright, and farther on, close opposite St. Pierre, twoislands clqse together — Herm and Jethou.

title: The manuscripts of His Grace the Duke of Portland, preserved at Welbeck abbey ...
snippet: In the afternoon passed the rivers Kirkle, Sark and Esk and came to Carlisle, twelve miles, a very pretty city, pleasantly situated on the river Eden and is surrounded with a wall three yards broad, the Castle formerly a very strong one belongs to the Duke of Portland.

title: The works of Robert Burns: with an account of his life, and criticism on his writings.
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: § Wallace, Laird of Craigie, who was second in command,  under Douglas earl of Ormond, at the fomous battle on the banks of Sark, fought anno 1448, That glorious victory was principally owing to the judiciqus conduct, and intrepid valour of the gallant Laird of Craigie, who died of his wounds alter the action.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns: containing his poems, songs, and correspondence.
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: Now Sark rins o'er the Solway sands.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns: containing his poems, songs, and correspondence.
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: under Douglas, Earl of Ormond, at the famous battle on the banks of Sark, fought anno 1448.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns: containing his poems, songs, and correspondence.

title: A holiday in bed, and other sketches.
author: Barrie, J. M.
snippet: Fifty marriages a month was no uncommon occurrence  at Gretna at that time, and it was then that the mansion was built which still stands about a hundred yards on the English side of the Sark.

title: A holiday in bed, and other sketches.
author: Barrie, J. M.
snippet: For the greater part of a century, there was a whirling of coaches and a clattering of horses across the border,  after which came marriage in England before a registrar, and an amendment of the Scotch law that required residence north of the Sark, on the part of one of the parties, for twenty-one days before the ceremony took place.

title: A holiday in bed, and other sketches.
author: Barrie, J. M.
snippet: But those were the great clattering days, when there were four famous marrying shops: the two rival inns of Springfield, that washed their hands of each other across the street, Mr. I^in ton's aristocratic  quarters at Gretna Hall, and the toll-bar on the right side of the Sark.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Murray, one of the Earl's brothers, fell in the battle; another, Hugh, Earl ofOrmond, was wounded and made prisoner, and immediately executed, notwithstanding his services at the battle of Sark.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The Scots pressedfuriously upon them, and as the little river Sark, which the English had passed atlow water, was now filled by the advancing tide, many of the fugitives lost theirlives.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The English had entered the Scottish border, and advanced beyond the smallriver Sark, when the armies came in presence of each other.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Archibald Douglas,Earl of Murray, one of the earl's brothers, falbngin the battle, his head was cut off, and sent to theKing, then before Abercorn; another, Hugh, Earlof Ormond, was wounded and made prisoner, andimmediately executed, notwithstanding his servicesat the battle of Sark.

title: The Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott. (Supplementary volume: containing notes, historical and illustrative, by the author, glossary, etc.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: For the same reason, perhaps, the Scots had theadvantage in the battle of Sark, and in two otheractions.

title: Early Travellers in Scotland. Edited by P. Hume Brown. [With maps.]
